content:
Yesterday James Dolan asked me this puzzle, and then told me the answer:

For any bicategory BBB there's a bicategory Adj(B)\mathrm{Adj}(B)Adj(B) with the same objects as BBB, where the morphisms are adjunctions in BBB, and the 2-morphisms are some well-known maps between adjunctions.
For example if B=CatB = \mathbf{Cat}B=Cat, Adj(B)\mathrm{Adj}(B)Adj(B) is the usual 2-category where morphisms are adjoint functors.
Puzzle. What are morphisms in Adj(Adj(B))\mathrm{Adj}(\mathrm{Adj}(B))Adj(Adj(B))?

You have four functors, two adjunctions. The internal-internal unit and counit actually pan out to give an internal unit and counit giving an adjunction between the left of the left and the left of the right, which of course forces the left of the right to be the same as the right of the left. So an adjoint triple.
Furthermore iterating this argument shows that the morphisms in Adjn(B)\mathrm{Adj}^n(B)Adjn(B) are adjoint (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-strings!

It's also worth noting that you can go one step below the level of functors. Functors are themselves adjunctions of profunctors. So adjoint nnn-tuples of functors are adjoint (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-tuples of profunctors.

Hmmm... I wonder if there's a universal way to go down a level. Does Adj\mathbf{Adj}Adj have an adjoint?

I don't know if Adj\mathrm{Adj}Adj has an adjoint, but it reminds me of something else: there's an adjunction between adjunctions and monads.

  • Every adjunction R:C→Set,L:Set→CR: C \to \mathsf{Set}, L: \mathsf{Set} \to CR:C→Set,L:Set→C gives a monad on Set\mathsf{Set}Set,

and

  • every monad TTT on Set\mathsf{Set}Set gives an adjunction of this sort where CCC is the Eilenberg-Moore category of TTT,

and the second construction can be seen as a right adjoint of the first, if I've got my head on straight. (I think the Kleisli construction is the left adjoint. But maybe it's the other way round!)

There should be some very general way to say this, but you need some conditions to build an "Eilenberg-Moore object" for a monad in a bicategory, I think. I guess a bunch of this was handled in Lack and Street's papers on the formal theory of monads, but I've never carefully read those.

Adj(Adj(B)\rm Adj(Adj(B)Adj(Adj(B) plays an important role in the specification of modal type theories for adjoint strings, particularly cohesion. When you specify a 2-category M\cal MM as the "mode theory" for a type theory, then every morphism in M\cal MM gives rise to an adjoint pair of modal operators, a "positive" one (with a left universal property) and a "negative" one (with a right universal property). Thus, if you want an adjoint triple of modal operators, you can achieve that by specifying an adjoint pair of morphisms in M\cal MM.

A more category-theoretic way of saying something similar is that if p:C→Bp:C\to Bp:C→B is a bifibration (i.e. both a fibration and an opfibration), then every morphism in BBB gives rise to an adjoint pair of functors between the fibers over its domain and codomain. Therefore, an adjoint pair of morphisms in BBB gives rise to an adjoint triple of functors between these fibers.

Oscar Cunningham said:

It's also worth noting that you can go one step below the level of functors. Functors are themselves adjunctions of profunctors. So adjoint nnn-tuples of functors are adjoint (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-tuples of profunctors.

Hmmm... I wonder if there's a universal way to go down a level. Does Adj\mathbf{Adj}Adj have an adjoint?

For a (complete enough) 222-category K\mathcal{K}K, one can construct its 222-category of two-sided discrete fibrations DFib(K)\mathbf{DFib}(\mathcal{K})DFib(K) . Given a 111-cell f∈K(a,b)f \in \mathcal{K}(a,b)f∈K(a,b), I think you get an adjoint pair (f/b)⊣(b/f)(f/b) \dashv (b/f)(f/b)⊣(b/f) in DFib(K)\mathbf{DFib}(\mathcal{K})DFib(K) by considering the adequate comma objects.
In the other direction, an adjunction u⊣vu \dashv vu⊣v of two-sided discrete fibrations (u∈DFib(K)(a,b),v∈DFib(K)(b,a)u \in \mathbf{DFib}(\mathcal{K})(a,b), v \in \mathbf{DFib}(\mathcal{K})(b,a)u∈DFib(K)(a,b),v∈DFib(K)(b,a)), induce representably a family of adjunctions between profunctors K(z,u):K(z,a)⇝K(z,b)\mathcal{K}(z, u) : \mathcal{K}(z, a) \leadsto \mathcal{K}(z, b)K(z,u):K(z,a)⇝K(z,b) and K(z,v):K(z,b)⇝K(z,a)\mathcal{K}(z, v) : \mathcal{K}(z, b) \leadsto \mathcal{K}(z, a)K(z,v):K(z,b)⇝K(z,a) naturally in z∈Kz \in \mathcal{K}z∈K, which then correspond to a family of functors K(z,a)→K(z,b)\mathcal{K}(z, a) \to \mathcal{K}(z, b)K(z,a)→K(z,b) naturally in zzz, hence to a 111-cell from aaa to bbb in K\mathcal{K}K.
This let me think that Adj(DFib(K))\mathbf{Adj}(\mathbf{DFib}(\mathcal{K}))Adj(DFib(K)) might be equivalent to K\mathcal{K}K whenever the construction makes sense, providing some kind of inverse construction to Adj\mathbf{Adj}Adj.

Interesting. So basically take the definition of profunctors in terms of functors and repeat it in an arbitrary 222-category. I can't quite see what this gives when you apply it to Adj(Cat)\mathbf{Adj}(\mathbf{Cat})Adj(Cat), but it's not just Cat\mathbf{Cat}Cat because there's a functor from 000 to 111 but if there was an object with an adjunction to both 000 and 111 then we could compose a functor going the other way.

A similar argument also shows that Adj\mathbf{Adj}Adj cannot be the underlying functor of a monad or a comonad.
If adj\mathbf{adj}adj is the walking adjunction (the 222-category with two objects and a single adjunction between these), then Adj(adj)=→\mathbf{Adj}(\mathbf{adj}) = \toAdj(adj)=→ the walking arrow 222-category and Adj(→)=2\mathbf{Adj}(\to) = \mathbb{2}Adj(→)=2 the discrete 222-category with two objects. There is no functor from →\to→ to 2\mathbb{2}2 and no functor from adj\mathbf{adj}adj to →\to→, so the former shows that Adj\mathbf{Adj}Adj cannot be equipped with a comultiplication, and the latter that it cannot be equipped with a unit.
There are functors between those categories but they're all constant. Is that enough?
Right, I have been too hasty. But in both cases you have to satisfy unitality/counitality equations that prevent constant functors to be valid solutions.
